articles.headline: Florida Lobster Got a Break on China Tariffs. Then Came Coronavirus.
articles.snippet: China, the biggest customer, took aim at the U.S. catch as the trade war escalated. Relief came this week, but now no one there is buying.
articles.abstract: China, the biggest customer, took aim at the U.S. catch as the trade war escalated. Relief came this week, but now no one there is buying.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARATHON, Fla. — Like other commercial fishermen along the east and west coasts, Ethan Wallace had been waiting 18 months for China — the world’s largest importer of live lobster — to lift its crushing retaliatory tariffs on American seafood that had whittled down his profits.

articles.headline: The Bernie Sanders Personality Test
articles.snippet: Some candidates try to soften their image to broaden their appeal. This one, not so much. But is there a “real” Bernie the public doesn’t get to see?
articles.abstract: Some candidates try to soften their image to broaden their appeal. This one, not so much. But is there a “real” Bernie the public doesn’t get to see?
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read more: Bernie Sanders has officially ended his 2020 presidential campaign.]
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Saudi Prince Detains Senior Members of Royal Family
articles.snippet: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has detained a brother of the king, a former crown prince and a cousin, royals who may have been seen as threats to his rule.
articles.abstract: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has detained a brother of the king, a former crown prince and a cousin, royals who may have been seen as threats to his rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a fresh episode of Saudi palace intrigue, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has detained three members of the royal family, including a brother of the king and a former crown prince who had been potential obstacles to his power.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: ‘The Only Choice Is to Wait for Death’
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of people fleeing Syria’s war ended up in Idlib city. But with the front line just five miles away, the city may not be a refuge much longer.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people fleeing Syria’s war ended up in Idlib city. But with the front line just five miles away, the city may not be a refuge much longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: IDLIB, Syria — Before the war in Syria, Idlib city, with its tree-lined avenues and white-stone buildings, was known for its calm, provincial air.

articles.headline: Spiraling Virus Fears Are Causing Financial Carnage
articles.snippet: A global disease outbreak isn’t the kind of risk that many investors were trained to react to.
articles.abstract: A global disease outbreak isn’t the kind of risk that many investors were trained to react to.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is nothing investors hate more than uncertainty. Right now, that is all there is.
articles.byline: By David Enrich, James B. Stewart and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: Trump Names Mark Meadows Chief of Staff, Ousting Mick Mulvaney
articles.snippet: Mr. Mulvaney, a central figure in the president’s pressure campaign on Ukraine, defied a subpoena to testify in the House impeachment inquiry and was never called by the Senate.
articles.abstract: Mr. Mulvaney, a central figure in the president’s pressure campaign on Ukraine, defied a subpoena to testify in the House impeachment inquiry and was never called by the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump on Friday pushed out Mick Mulvaney, his acting White House chief of staff, and replaced him with Representative Mark Meadows, a stalwart conservative ally, shaking up his team in the middle of one of the biggest crises of his presidency.

articles.headline: The Market Is Rocky. Will Target-Date Funds Change Their Strategy?
articles.snippet: Not much. That’s partly because they’re investing for the long term, and partly because they’re protecting you from your own worst instincts.
articles.abstract: Not much. That’s partly because they’re investing for the long term, and partly because they’re protecting you from your own worst instincts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The professionals are in charge, and they may just protect you from yourself.

articles.headline: A Sanders Voter, Weary of Debt at 29: ‘I Have Nothing to Lose’
articles.snippet: Brian Michelz has never worn a political T-shirt or been to a campaign rally. But when he voted for the first time in his life, it was for Bernie Sanders. What will he do if Mr. Sanders loses?
articles.abstract: Brian Michelz has never worn a political T-shirt or been to a campaign rally. But when he voted for the first time in his life, it was for Bernie Sanders. What will he do if Mr. Sanders loses?
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Debt has dogged Brian Michelz his entire adult life.

articles.headline: Vigilantes in Greece Say ‘No More’ to Migrants
articles.snippet: Frustrated and exhausted by the lingering problems from the 2015 crisis, Greeks once generous with refugees are turning hostile, some violently.
articles.abstract: Frustrated and exhausted by the lingering problems from the 2015 crisis, Greeks once generous with refugees are turning hostile, some violently.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVROS, Greece — The farmers and pensioners wore black clothes and heavy boots, imitating Greece’s special forces, and trod along a rural road on a night patrol looking for migrants trying to cross the northern land border with Turkey. “We’ll get you next time!” they shouted at a small group of men who had made it over and fled.

articles.headline: Erik Prince Recruits Ex-Spies to Help Infiltrate Liberal Groups
articles.snippet: Mr. Prince, a contractor close to the Trump administration, contacted veteran spies for operations by Project Veritas, the conservative group known for conducting stings on news organizations and other groups.
articles.abstract: Mr. Prince, a contractor close to the Trump administration, contacted veteran spies for operations by Project Veritas, the conservative group known for conducting stings on news organizations and other groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Erik Prince, the security contractor with close ties to the Trump administration, has in recent years helped recruit former American and British spies for secretive intelligence-gathering operations that included infiltrating Democratic congressional campaigns, labor organizations and other groups considered hostile to the Trump agenda, according to interviews and documents.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: China May Be Beating the Coronavirus, at a Painful Cost
articles.snippet: Beijing says its heavy-handed measures are working. Can other countries battling the outbreak learn from its efforts — or is the cure worse than the disease?
articles.abstract: Beijing says its heavy-handed measures are working. Can other countries battling the outbreak learn from its efforts — or is the cure worse than the disease?
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As the new coronavirus races around the world, tanking markets, cutting off global travel and suspending school for hundreds of millions of children, governments are desperate for ways to contain it.

articles.headline: Italy Locks Down Much of the Country’s North Over the Coronavirus
articles.snippet: The restrictions affect Milan and the regions that serve as Italy’s economic engine, and are the most sweeping measures outside China.
articles.abstract: The restrictions affect Milan and the regions that serve as Italy’s economic engine, and are the most sweeping measures outside China.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s government early Sunday took the extraordinary step of locking down much of the country’s north, restricting movement for about a quarter of the Italian population in regions that serve as the country’s economic engine.

articles.headline: Inside Trump Administration, Debate Raged Over What to Tell Public
articles.snippet: The administration’s response to the coronavirus has repeatedly matched public health experts against a hesitant White House, where worry of panic dominates.
articles.abstract: The administration’s response to the coronavirus has repeatedly matched public health experts against a hesitant White House, where worry of panic dominates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of conflicting signals from the Trump administration about the coronavirus, the government’s top health officials decided late last month that when President Trump returned from a trip to India, they would tell him they had to be more blunt about the dangers of the outbreak.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Sheri Fink and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Wall Street Had 2 Terrible Weeks. Here’s How 7 Traders Dealt With It.
articles.snippet: As anxiety about coronavirus gave way to fear, investors dumped shares, watched the news and fielded client calls. “I have no energy left to speak.”
articles.abstract: As anxiety about coronavirus gave way to fear, investors dumped shares, watched the news and fielded client calls. “I have no energy left to speak.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The past two weeks were among the worst in recent Wall Street history, as anxiety about the coronavirus outbreak gave way to alarm and drove panicked investors to sell their stock holdings, obliterating roughly $2 trillion in wealth.
articles.byline: By James B. Stewart, Kate Kelly, Matt Phillips and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Won Michigan in 2016. Tuesday’s Primary Looks Much Tougher.
articles.snippet: Four years ago, Mr. Sanders drew support from some voters who didn’t like Hillary Clinton. Joe Biden is poised to do well with black Democrats and college-educated white voters.
articles.abstract: Four years ago, Mr. Sanders drew support from some voters who didn’t like Hillary Clinton. Joe Biden is poised to do well with black Democrats and college-educated white voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Four years ago, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont scored an upset win over Hillary Clinton in the Michigan Democratic primary, reviving his insurgent candidacy one week after his political prospects dimmed because of Super Tuesday losses.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Failures on the Diamond Princess Shadow Another Cruise Ship Outbreak
articles.snippet: An alert about a coronavirus infection sat in an unmonitored inbox. A cruise doctor saw “no point” in disinfecting the ship. And Japan disregarded medical guidelines to contain an outbreak.
articles.abstract: An alert about a coronavirus infection sat in an unmonitored inbox. A cruise doctor saw “no point” in disinfecting the ship. And Japan disregarded medical guidelines to contain an outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: The email to Princess Cruises was peppered with typos and awkward grammar, but the warning was unmistakable. An 80-year-old passenger had tested positive for the new coronavirus after getting off the Diamond Princess cruise ship in Hong Kong.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Motoko Rich and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Where Mermaids Play, a Nasty Water Fight
articles.snippet: Nestlé wants to draw more spring water from a northern Florida site owned by a local family — but environmentalists are pushing back.
articles.abstract: Nestlé wants to draw more spring water from a northern Florida site owned by a local family — but environmentalists are pushing back.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGH SPRINGS, Fla. — One by one, the mermaids dived into the water.

articles.headline: For Trump, Coronavirus Proves to Be an Enemy He Can’t Tweet Away
articles.snippet: A president who is at his strongest politically when he has a human target to attack has found it harder to confront a growing outbreak that has rattled the country.
articles.abstract: A president who is at his strongest politically when he has a human target to attack has found it harder to confront a growing outbreak that has rattled the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Defending against criticism of his handling of the coronavirus, President Trump suggested the other day that he could hardly have been expected to be ready for such an unexpected crisis.

articles.headline: On Day 1 of Lockdown, Italian Officials Urge Citizens to Abide by Rules
articles.snippet: Italy’s prime minister implored the public to cooperate in the largest clampdown against the coronavirus in the Western world. “We are the new Wuhan,” one Milan resident said.
articles.abstract: Italy’s prime minister implored the public to cooperate in the largest clampdown against the coronavirus in the Western world. “We are the new Wuhan,” one Milan resident said.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte ended his 2:15 a.m. news conference to announce the extraordinary lockdown of Italy’s north with a plea that other heads of state may not have felt compelled to make.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Emma Bubola

articles.headline: What Bernie Sanders Gets Right About the Media
articles.snippet: The senator’s sweeping critique of coverage has more merit than we in the media like to admit.
articles.abstract: The senator’s sweeping critique of coverage has more merit than we in the media like to admit.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a BuzzFeed News colleague and I sat down with Bernie Sanders in his Capitol Hill office in 2015, he started with a thank you — for doing what you do to provide an alternative to the corporate media.

articles.headline: In Coronavirus Fight, China’s Vulnerable Fall Through the Cracks
articles.snippet: In locked-down cities like Wuhan, isolated seniors and disabled people have largely had to fend for themselves.
articles.abstract: In locked-down cities like Wuhan, isolated seniors and disabled people have largely had to fend for themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lucifer Zhang, who is deaf and cannot speak, was able to get by on her $140 monthly stipend from the government. Then China locked down her home city, Wuhan, in late January to contain the coronavirus outbreak.

articles.headline: How the Trump Campaign Took Over the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The president’s campaign manager and his allies commandeered Republican voter data and fund-raising engines, consolidating power — and profiting — in ways never before possible.
articles.abstract: The president’s campaign manager and his allies commandeered Republican voter data and fund-raising engines, consolidating power — and profiting — in ways never before possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s campaign manager and a circle of allies have seized control of the Republican Party’s voter data and fund-raising apparatus, using a network of private businesses whose operations and ownership are cloaked in secrecy, largely exempt from federal disclosure.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Financial System Faces Biggest Test Since 2008 as Coronavirus Spreads
articles.snippet: The Trump administration has chipped away at the post-crisis regulatory system, moves that could expose financial system vulnerabilities if the economic threat from the virus intensifies.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration has chipped away at the post-crisis regulatory system, moves that could expose financial system vulnerabilities if the economic threat from the virus intensifies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus outbreak is putting the resilience of the financial system to its biggest test since the 2008 financial crisis, a critical moment that comes as the Trump administration continues efforts to relax Wall Street regulation.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek
